metadata.subject: In the shadow of quantitative easing, party like it is 1788

relationships.description: ECB's quantitative easing policies are causing insolvency concerns for insurers and pension plans
German anger over eurozone deposit insurance scheme contrasted with Italian government cynicism over budget policy

analysis.purpose: To analyze and warn about the negative consequences of quantitative easing policies on European financial stability
analysis.significance: Provides expert analysis of ECB policies and their potential to cause systemic financial problems in Europe

notable_quotes: Quantitative easing is leading to the insolvency of life insurers and defined benefit pension plans
The low interest rate scenario used in the stress test has already arrived, and the current yield curve is already lower than that used in the test
In the coming holidays, you should party like it is 1788
red_flags: Systemic financial risk to pension systems

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found - this is financial analysis content

illegal_activity.description: This is a Financial Times news article analyzing economic policy, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: Financial Times article by John Dizard
References to press releases and media coverage of economic policies

public_knowledge.context: This is a published Financial Times article that would have been publicly available online

analysis.summary: This Financial Times article from November 2015 analyzes the negative consequences of quantitative easing policies by the European Central Bank, warning that these policies are leading to the insolvency of life insurers and defined benefit pension plans across Europe, with particular concern for the upcoming implementation of Solvency II regulations.
